direct_enhancements.reason: Both methods retrieve elements from the queue but with different behaviors (peek returns the element without removing, poll removes the element).
Both methods retrieve the head of the queue, but element throws an exception if the queue is empty, while peek returns null.
Both methods access elements in the queue, but get allows accessing any element by index, while peek only accesses the head.
Both methods interact with the queue's state, but remove modifies the queue by removing the head element, while peek only reads it.

enhanced_by.reason: Adding elements to the queue is necessary to set up a non-empty state for peeking.
Clearing the queue can be used to set up an empty state for testing peek's behavior with an empty queue.
Removing elements can be used to change the queue's state before peeking, ensuring different scenarios are tested.
Both methods handle the queue's empty state similarly, making element useful for asserting peek's behavior in such cases.
get can be used to assert the correctness of the element returned by peek, especially in non-empty queue scenarios.
